facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 959 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 959 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated March 16, 1963 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in Second Appeal No. 86 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 16, 1963 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Second Appeal No. 86 of 1962.

facts.text: Appellant brought a suit for redemption of certain mortgaged property.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant brought a suit for redemption of certain mortgaged property.

facts.text: Preliminary decree passed in the suit on February 3, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary decree was passed in the suit on February 3, 1954.

facts.text: Preliminary decree specified amount due as principal and interest upto a certain date, future interest at 3% per annum on certain sum till realisation.

anchor.surface_text: It specified the amount due as principal and the amount due as interest upto a certain date. It also provided that future interest was to be paid at three per

facts.text: Preliminary decree provided payment by July 15, 1964 or extended time, parties bear own costs.

facts.text: Appeals by both parties from preliminary decree to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: There were appeals by both parties from this preliminary decree to the High Court.

facts.text: Trial court extended time for payment upto August 15, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime the appellant had prayed for extension of time and the trial companyrt had extended time for making payment upto August 15, 1954.

facts.text: Appellant applied to High Court for stay of deposit order till disposal of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: About the same time, the appellant applied to the High Court praying that the order requiring him to deposit the decretal amount by August 15, 1954 be stayed

issues.text: Whether the deposit made before the final decree was passed was within time under O.XXXIV r.8 even if after the time fixed under O.XXXIV r.7

anchor.surface_text: The High Court agreed with the Additional District Judge. and held that in view of O.XXXIV r. 8 1  the deposit made on April 9, 1959 before the final decree was passed on April 18, 1959 was within time, even though the money might have been deposited after the time fixed under O.XXXIV r.7.

issues.text: Whether the appellant had deposited the entire amount due under the preliminary decree, or whether the shortage on account of extra interest under the stay undertaking had to be included

anchor.surface_text: The only question raised on behalf of the appellant is that he had deposited the amount which was strictly due under the preliminary decree and something more. The shortage was only on account of the sum due as a result of the stay order passed by the High Court by which he was required to pay six per cent per annum more as interest for the duration of the stay.

issues.text: Whether the extra interest amount undertaken for the stay period can be said to be within the amount adjudged due in respect of subsequent costs, charges, expenses and interests under O.XXXIV r.7 cl.(c)

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether this amount can be said to be within the words the amount adjudged due in respect of subsequent costs, charges, expenses and interests.

arguments.court_reasoning: Extra amount from undertaking not within 'amount adjudged due in respect of subsequent costs, charges, expenses and interests' under O.XXXIV r.7(1)(c)

arguments.claim: Extra interest from undertaking is within 'the amount adjudged due in respect of subsequent costs, charges, expenses and interests' under O.XXXIV r.7(1)(c)

anchor.surface_text: Order XXXIV r. 7 (1) lays down what a preliminary decree should contain and we are in the present case concerned with cls. (b) and (c) thereof. In this case the preliminary decree had declared the amount due upto a certain date towards principal and interest

arguments.claim: Extra amount from stay undertaking cannot come within 'subsequent costs, charges, expenses and interests'; not adjudged; undertaking separate

anchor.surface_text: Now under O.XXXIV r. 7 (1) (c) (i) and (ii) what the appellant had to deposit was the amount found under the preliminary decree and also the amount adjudged due in respect of subsequent costs, charges, expenses and interests

arguments.claim: On this view there would be no way to enforce the appellant's undertaking to pay extra interest

anchor.surface_text: It is however urged that on this view there would be no way to enforce the appellants undertaking to pay extra interest for the period of stay.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: umberhing account of subsequent charges, companyts, expenses and interests, for numberhing was adjudged in respect of these. Nor as we have said alrea

arguments.court_reasoning: Court can insist on honouring undertaking before passing final decree; separate enforcement possible

holdings.text: Under O.XXXIV, r. 8(1) the mortgagor can deposit all amounts due under O.XXXIV r. 7(1) before the final decree debarring him from all rights to redeem is passed.

anchor.surface_text: Under O.XXXIV, r. 8 1  the mortgagor can deposit all amounts due under O.XXXIV r. 7 1  before the final decree debarring him from all rights to redeem is passed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain reading of Rule 8(1) permits deposit at any time before the final debarring decree, overriding the fixed date in preliminary decree under Rule 7.

holdings.text: The extra amount payable on account of the undertaking given by the mortgagor for obtaining stay of deposit order cannot come within the amount adjudged due in respect of subsequent costs, charges, expenses and interests under O.XXXIV r. 7(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this extra amount which was to be paid on account of the undertaking of the appellant for the purpose of stay cannot come within the words the amount adjudged due in respect of subsequent costs, charges, expenses and interests.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Extra interest stems from independent stay order and undertaking, not incorporated into or adjudged under the preliminary decree; requires prior adjudication to qualify as 'adjudged due'.

holdings.text: The appellant deposited the entire amount due under the preliminary decree as required under O.XXXIV r. 8(1) and was entitled to a final decree for redemption.

anchor.surface_text: As we have come to the conclusion that this amount due on account of the undertaking given by the appellant in the matter of stay cannot be taken to be part of the amount due under the preliminary decree, it must be held that the appellant was entitled to a final decree in his favour.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed that amount per decree plus interest was deposited; extra stay interest excluded per interpretation of r.7(1)(c), satisfying deposit requirement before final decree.

holdings.text: The court can insist that the mortgagor honour his undertaking to pay extra interest before passing the final decree in his favour.

anchor.surface_text: It is however urged that on this view there would be no way to enforce the appellants undertaking to pay extra interest for the period of stay. We do not think so. It would in our opinion be in order for the court to insist before it passed the final decree that the appellant honours his undertaking.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undertaking enforceable as condition precedent to final decree or separately, avoiding policy concern of non-enforceability.

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support
Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this extra amount which was to be paid on account of the undertaking of the appellant for the purpose of stay cannot come within the words the amount adjudged due in respect of subsequent costs, charges, expenses and interests.

We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and restore the order of the Additional District Judge. The respondent will be entitled to withdraw the amount deposited by the appellant including the amount deposited on April 21, 1962 on the

edges.explanation: Holding that entire amount under preliminary decree deposited addresses i2

anchor.surface_text: As we have come to the conclusion that this amount due on account of the undertaking given by the appellant in the matter of stay cannot be taken to be part of the amount due under the preliminary decree, it must be held that the appellant was entitled to a final decree in his favour.

We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and restore the order of the Additional District Judge. The respondent will be entitled to withdraw the amount deposited by the appellant including the amount deposited on April 21, 1962 on the
